article.head: State of the climate
article.tag: Climate Action Note – data you need to know

text.p: The world is in a climate emergency – ‘a code red for humanity’. The concentration of GHG emissions in the atmosphere is wreaking havoc across the world threatening lives, economy, health and food. We are far from securing a global temperature rise safely below 1.5°C as promised in the Paris Agreement. With a baseline in 1990, some countries are emitting more, some the same and some are emitting less.
The UNEP Climate Action Note shows you the global state of the climate emergency and its development.

article.title: Emissions
article.head: GHG emissions are choking our world, mitigation opportunities exist but GHG emissions continue to rise

text.p: To limit global temperature rise to a safe 1.5°C, as promised in the Paris Agreement, countries must cut 30 gigatonnes of greenhouse gas emissions annually by 2030. The necessary solutions exist yet at the moment more and more GHG emissions are entering the atmosphere making it harder to keep the planet safe.

article.title: Per capita
article.head: Individual carbon footprint varies a lot and it falls along wealth lines

text.p: The world’s wealthiest 1 percent emit more than twice the emissions of the poorest half combined. That is why developed nation must step up to make rapid and large-scale emission reduction and support developing countries as they build low-carbon economies and make adequate climate adaptation.

article.title: Trends
article.head: Progress is being made but it is insufficient and all countries need to step up

text.p: We can stay safe below 1.5°C temperature rise as set out in the Paris Agreement using existing solutions. They include renewable energy, green hydrogen and modern bioenergy — and government subsidies and support could be directed to push towards low-carbon and green policies. We need to scale up the green transition and reduce GHG emissions by fivefold to stay safe. Explore the UNEP Six-sector solution.
